comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I did a bit of Troving - he was Richard J. Burke, and resigned from the NSW ASA in June 1902 "owing to pressure of business" - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14456212 . Intriguing!

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] and did you notice in that article a note from a 'Mr Kellerman' asking about a ladies swimming club... Could be Annette's father as it is around the same time!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] I didn't notice that - well spotted!  There is much more to be discovered about R. Burke.  My instinct tells me this portrait is c.1890 (?).

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] c.1890 is a reasonable estimation. Trove reveals Ruben's & Co. were active between 1890 and 1894. The first advertisements appear under the moniker Ruben's Studio in April 1890 (trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/65343063). Thomas Charles Cleave became the principle photographer in September 1890 (trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/65344957), joining Oliver Godfrey in an informal partnership, and shortly after the business is advertised as Ruben's & Co.. Cleave left the struggling studio in August 1891 and returned to Sydney (trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/62727186). In March 1894 the business was sold (trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/62958069), however the new operator, Herbert Edward Selby Felton, was not able to keep it going, and applied for bankruptcy in October 1894 (trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/62957971). So, the portrait must date between September 1890 and October 1894, and the photographer is either Godfrey, Cleave, or Felton. Another example of the portrait work of Ruben's & Co. - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/ljmck/5646398184/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Brilliant - I knew you would find something!  It never occurred to me that it was George Street IN Bathurst - I misread it as George Street AND Bathurst - whoops!

I wonder if Richard J. Burke was living in Bathurst in the early 1890s?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] "Wynolah", Balmain in September 1890 (trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13789477). "Wynolah" was on Birchgrove Road (trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/71253759). There is no mention of the Burke's in relation to the wedding that was celebrated there in June 1891. Maybe they had moved to Bathurst ...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Re your first comment, what is even more intriguing is that he had resigned his position of honorary secretary before, in August 1897, "through pressure of private duties" - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/71277172

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: Wow we leave you guys for an evening and look what happens! :) What a fantastic amount of info - in fact I just had a look and in the Sands Directory for 1898 and 1899 there is an entry for Richard Burke at Burns Hut Farm Brewongle, just outside of Bathurst. Could be the man? But then Richard Burke is not an uncommon name...
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
